statements.text: Watts & Strogatz introduced models of networks of coupled dynamical systems ranging from regular to random to explore small-world networks.
They use a random rewiring procedure to interpolate between regular and random networks using rewiring probability p.
They find that for intermediate p, networks have high clustering like regular and small path lengths like random, thus small-world networks.
Small-world networks reduce emergence of cooperation in iterated Prisoner's dilemma models.
Small-world connectivity enhances performance of cellular automata density classification tasks.
Small-world coupling allows near-mean-field synchronizability of phase oscillators even with fewer edges.
They model infectious disease spread on small-world graphs, showing critical infectiousness r_half decreases with p.
For a maximally infectious disease, the global infection time T mirrors L(p), so disease spreads quickly in small-world networks.
Empirical examples of small-world networks include the film actor collaboration graph, the power grid, and the C. elegans neural network.
They define characteristic path length L as average shortest path length and clustering coefficient C as average cliquishness in the networks.
Shortcuts are long-range edges introduced by rewiring that drastically reduce L but minimally affect C.
